questions.stem: A psychologist providing therapy to an adult client learns during a session that the client's 7-year-old child is being physically abused by the client's partner. Under Standard 4.05 (Disclosures), which statement is most accurate regarding the psychologist's obligation?

options.text: The psychologist must maintain confidentiality because the child is not the client
The psychologist is permitted to disclose confidential information to protect the child from harm, as mandated by law
The psychologist should wait until the next session to determine if the abuse is ongoing
The psychologist should discuss the situation with the client's partner before reporting

questions.explanation: Standard 4.05(b)(3) permits disclosure of confidential information without consent when mandated by law to protect the client or others from harm. All states have mandatory child abuse reporting laws that require psychologists (as mandated reporters) to report suspected child abuse. This legal mandate takes precedence over confidentiality. The psychologist must report to child protective services regardless of whether the child is the identified client. Waiting or confronting the alleged abuser could endanger the child.

questions.stem: Standard 4.01 (Maintaining Confidentiality) requires psychologists to take reasonable precautions to protect confidential information. In the age of electronic health records and telepsychology, this standard most likely requires psychologists to:

options.text: Avoid using any electronic communication with clients
Use encryption, secure platforms, and take measures to protect electronically stored and transmitted information
Store all records in paper format only
Have clients sign a waiver releasing the psychologist from responsibility for electronic breaches

questions.explanation: Standard 4.01 requires reasonable precautions to protect confidential information. In the digital age, this includes using encrypted communications, HIPAA-compliant platforms for telepsychology, secure electronic health record systems, strong passwords, and other reasonable measures. The standard does not prohibit electronic communication but requires appropriate safeguards. A waiver would not fulfill this obligation, and requiring paper-only records would be impractical and potentially limit access to care.

questions.stem: A psychologist is conducting couple therapy. One partner calls separately to disclose an extramarital affair and asks the psychologist not to tell the other partner. According to Standard 4.02 (Discussing the Limits of Confidentiality), what should have happened at the outset of therapy?

options.text: The psychologist should have established a no-secrets policy or clarified how such situations would be handled
The psychologist should have promised absolute confidentiality to each individual
The psychologist has no obligation to discuss confidentiality procedures in couple therapy
The psychologist should have anticipated this situation and refused to see them as a couple

questions.explanation: Standard 4.02 requires psychologists to discuss the relevant limits of confidentiality at the outset of the relationship. In couple therapy, this is especially important because the 'client' may be defined differently (the couple vs. each individual). Best practice requires establishing a clear policy at intake about how individual disclosures will be handled (e.g., a no-secrets policy, or a policy of keeping individual disclosures confidential). Without such a policy, the psychologist is in a difficult bind.

questions.stem: A psychologist has been treating a 17-year-old client for major depressive disorder. During a session, the client discloses detailed plans to harm a specific classmate. Under the Tarasoff ruling and Standard 4.05 (Disclosures) of the APA Ethics Code, the psychologist's primary ethical and legal obligation is to:

options.text: Maintain absolute confidentiality because the client is a minor and the threat may not be credible
Wait until the next session to assess whether the threat persists before taking action
Take reasonable steps to protect the identifiable potential victim, which may include warning the intended victim and notifying law enforcement
Contact only the client's parents and allow them to decide whether to warn the potential victim

questions.explanation: The Tarasoff v. Regents of the University of California (1976) ruling established a duty to protect identifiable third parties from serious threats of harm. When a client makes a credible threat against an identifiable victim, the therapist has a duty to take reasonable steps to protect the potential victim. Standard 4.05 of the APA Ethics Code permits disclosure of confidential information without consent when mandated by law or to protect the client or others from harm. The psychologist should warn the identifiable potential victim and/or notify law enforcement. While notifying parents of a minor is also appropriate, it alone does not fulfill the duty to protect. Waiting or maintaining silence when a credible, specific threat exists would be both ethically and legally inappropriate.

questions.stem: Standard 4.03 (Recording) requires that psychologists obtain informed consent before electronically recording sessions. A psychologist wants to video record therapy sessions for supervision purposes. Which approach is most consistent with this standard?

options.text: Record sessions and inform clients afterward if the recording will be used
Obtain informed consent before recording, explaining the purpose, who will view the recording, and how it will be stored and eventually destroyed
Post a notice in the waiting room that sessions may be recorded
Recording for supervision is exempt from informed consent requirements because it serves an educational purpose

questions.explanation: Standard 4.03 requires prior informed consent before recording. This means the client must be informed before recording begins, not after. The consent should specify the purpose of the recording (supervision), who will view it (the supervisor and possibly supervision group), how it will be securely stored, and when/how it will be destroyed. A waiting room notice is insufficient because it does not constitute individualized informed consent. No exemption exists for supervision or educational purposes; these uses still require explicit consent.

questions.stem: Under Standard 4.05 (Disclosures), psychologists may disclose confidential information without consent of the individual in which of the following situations? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: As mandated by law (e.g., mandatory reporting of child abuse)
To protect the client or others from harm
When a client is irritating to work with
To obtain payment for services from a collection agency without client authorization
To obtain appropriate professional consultations

questions.explanation: Standard 4.05 permits disclosure without consent when: mandated by law (A), permitted by law for a valid purpose such as protecting the client/patient, psychologist, or others from harm (B), and to obtain appropriate professional consultations (E). Being irritated by a client (C) is never grounds for breach of confidentiality. Using collection agencies requires careful attention to disclosure limits; sending to collections without proper authorization (D) is not permitted under this standard.

questions.stem: Standard 4.06 (Consultations) addresses maintaining confidentiality when consulting. Which actions are consistent with this standard? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Disclosing only information necessary for the purpose of the consultation
Not disclosing information that could lead to identification of the client when possible
Sharing the complete client file with any colleague who asks
Informing consultants about the limits of their use of disclosed information
Sharing all details freely since consultation falls under the treatment exception

questions.explanation: Standard 4.06 requires that when consulting with colleagues, psychologists do not disclose information that could reasonably lead to identification of the client unless they have obtained prior consent or the disclosure cannot be avoided. They should share only information necessary for the consultation purpose (A), protect identifying information when possible (B), and inform consultants about confidentiality limits (D). Sharing complete files (C) or all details freely (E) would violate the principle of minimum necessary disclosure.

questions.stem: Standard 4.04 (Minimizing Intrusions on Privacy) requires psychologists to include in written and oral reports only information germane to the purpose for which the communication is made. Which of the following scenarios violate this standard? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: A psychologist writing a disability evaluation includes extensive detail about the client's sexual history, which is unrelated to the disability claim
A psychologist providing a treatment summary to a new provider includes relevant diagnostic and treatment history
A psychologist's letter to a school regarding a child's learning accommodations includes irrelevant details about the parents' marital problems disclosed in family therapy
A psychologist's progress note includes observations relevant to the treatment plan and diagnosis
A psychologist sends a client's complete unredacted file to an insurance company that requested only a treatment summary

questions.explanation: Standard 4.04 requires minimizing intrusions on privacy by including only germane information. Including irrelevant sexual history in a disability evaluation (A), disclosing parents' marital problems in a school accommodation letter (C), and sending a complete unredacted file when only a summary was requested (E) all violate this principle. Providing relevant diagnostic and treatment history to a new provider (B) and documenting treatment-relevant observations in progress notes (D) are consistent with the standard.

questions.stem: Standard 4.07 (Use of Confidential Information for Didactic or Other Purposes) addresses the use of client information in teaching, writing, or public presentations. Which actions are consistent with this standard? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Disguising identifying information so that the client cannot be reasonably identified
Obtaining consent from the client before using their case in a published case study
Using a client's case in a class lecture verbatim, including the client's real name and workplace
Creating a composite case that draws from multiple clients so no single individual can be identified
Disclosing confidential client material in a textbook chapter without either consent or disguise because the information is clinically interesting

questions.explanation: Standard 4.07 requires that psychologists either disguise confidential information so individuals cannot be reasonably identified (A), obtain client consent (B), or both. Creating composite cases (D) is another acceptable approach. Using real names and identifying details without consent (C) is a clear violation. Disclosing without consent or disguise because the material is interesting (E) violates the standard regardless of the educational value. The standard applies to all didactic purposes including teaching, writing, and presentations.

questions.stem: An ethics educator is evaluating student responses about confidentiality and record keeping. Which of the following statements accurately reflect APA Ethics Code requirements? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Standard 4.05 permits disclosure without consent when mandated by law or when necessary to protect the client, psychologist, or others from harm
Standard 6.02 requires that psychologists maintain confidentiality in creating, storing, accessing, transferring, and disposing of records under their control
Psychologists may withhold client records regardless of circumstances if they believe release would be harmful, even when legally compelled

Standard 4.01 requires psychologists to take reasonable precautions to protect confidential information obtained through or stored in any medium, recognizing that the extent and limits of confidentiality may be regulated by law or established by institutional rules
Psychologists have an absolute duty under the Ethics Code to warn all potential victims whenever any client expresses anger toward another person

questions.explanation: Standard 4.05 does permit disclosure without consent when mandated by law or to protect from harm, establishing exceptions to confidentiality (A). Standard 6.02 requires confidentiality throughout the record lifecycle (B). Standard 4.01 establishes the obligation to protect confidential information across all media (D). Psychologists cannot withhold records when legally compelled (C)â€”they must comply with valid legal orders while taking steps to protect client welfare. The duty to warn/protect requires a specific, credible, imminent threat to an identifiable victim (E), not merely expressions of anger.

questions.stem: Match each confidentiality scenario to the most applicable Standard 4 provision:

rows.text: A psychologist discusses client information at a dinner party without removing identifying details
A psychologist fails to discuss confidentiality limits at the start of treatment
A psychologist video records a session without the client's knowledge or consent
A psychologist shares unnecessary personal details about a client in a report to a school

columns.text: Standard 4.02: Discussing the Limits of Confidentiality

questions.explanation: Discussing identifiable client information socially (row1) is a direct violation of Standard 4.01 (Maintaining Confidentiality). Failing to discuss limits at intake (row2) violates Standard 4.02 (Discussing the Limits of Confidentiality). Recording without consent (row3) violates Standard 4.03 (Recording), which requires prior consent. Including unnecessary personal details in a report (row4) violates Standard 4.04 (Minimizing Intrusions on Privacy), which requires that only germane information be included in reports.

questions.stem: Match each clinical situation to the correct application of confidentiality principles under the APA Ethics Code:

rows.text: A psychologist uses a client's case in a published article after changing the name, age, and location
A psychologist is subpoenaed to testify and releases records without client consent or court order
A psychologist discusses a client case during peer consultation, using only the client's first name
A psychologist working in a military setting is ordered by a commanding officer to disclose therapy content

columns.text: Consistent with Standard 4.07 (adequate disguise of identifying information)
Violation of Standard 4.01 (subpoena alone does not override confidentiality)
Potential violation of Standard 4.06 (first name may be sufficient to identify)
Requires balancing Standard 4.01 with institutional/legal obligations and advocating for client confidentiality

questions.explanation: Changing name, age, and location when publishing is generally adequate disguise under Standard 4.07, though the psychologist should consider whether the combination of unchanged clinical details could still identify the client. Releasing records upon subpoena alone, without client consent or court order, violates Standard 4.01. Using a client's first name during consultation may violate Standard 4.06 if the name plus other discussed details could lead to identification. Military settings create complex balancing situations where Standard 4.01 obligations must be weighed against military regulations and command authority, requiring the psychologist to advocate for maximum confidentiality possible within the institutional framework.

questions.stem: For each practice setting, select ALL situations where Standard 4.02 (Discussing Limits of Confidentiality) presents unique challenges:

columns.text: Individual disclosures may conflict with therapy goals
Other group members may breach confidentiality
Command or organizational reporting requirements may override clinical confidentiality
Confidentiality limits are identical to individual therapy

questions.explanation: Couple/family therapy: Individual disclosures (secrets) can conflict with therapy goals, and the 'client' definition (individual vs. couple/family) is often ambiguous. Group therapy: The psychologist cannot guarantee that other group members will maintain confidentiality; the 'client' includes multiple individuals. Military/institutional settings: Command reporting requirements and fitness-for-duty evaluations may limit confidentiality; the client (individual vs. organization) is often unclear. None of these settings have confidentiality limits identical to individual therapy.

questions.stem: For each Standard 4 provision, select ALL situations that would constitute a violation:

columns.text: Leaving client files visible on a desk in a shared office where cleaning staff can see them
Including a client's HIV status in a report to an employer requesting a fitness-for-duty evaluation for a desk job
Disclosing a client's substance use history to the client's spouse without consent, when there is no risk to others
Reporting suspected child abuse to CPS as required by state law
Sending therapy records via unencrypted email at the client's explicit written request

questions.explanation: Standard 4.01 violations: Leaving files visible to cleaning staff (col1) fails to take reasonable precautions; sending records via unencrypted email (col5) is problematic even with client request because the psychologist must take reasonable precautions to protect confidentiality and should inform the client of the risks. Standard 4.04 violation: Including HIV status in a fitness report for a desk job (col2) discloses information not germane to the purpose. Standard 4.05 violation: Disclosing substance use to a spouse without consent when there is no safety risk (col3) is not permitted under any exception. Reporting child abuse (col4) is mandated by law and permitted under Standard 4.05.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about confidentiality and its limits:

Under Standard 4.01, psychologists have a primary obligation to protect [BLANK1] information obtained through their professional work. Standard 4.02 requires that psychologists discuss the [BLANK2] of confidentiality at the outset of the professional relationship. Exceptions to confidentiality include situations where disclosure is [BLANK3] by law, such as mandatory reporting of child abuse. Under the [BLANK4] duty, established by Tarasoff v. Regents, psychologists may have a duty to protect identifiable third parties from serious harm. When releasing records, Standard 4.04 requires psychologists to minimize [BLANK5] of confidential information.
questions.explanation: Standard 4 addresses confidentiality comprehensively: maintaining confidential information (4.01), discussing relevant limits at outset (4.02), exceptions when mandated or permitted by law (4.05), and minimizing privacy intrusions in disclosures (4.04). The Tarasoff decision established the duty to warn/protect identifiable potential victims, which varies by state but is widely recognized as a key confidentiality exception.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about confidentiality in specialized practice settings:

In group therapy, Standard 4.02 requires psychologists to discuss that while the psychologist will maintain confidentiality, [BLANK1] may not be bound by the same obligations. When providing telepsychology services, Standard 4.01 requires psychologists to ensure that [BLANK2] are used for communication and record storage. Standard 4.07 addresses the use of confidential information for [BLANK3] purposes, requiring either consent or adequate disguise. In forensic settings, Standard 4.02 is especially important because the [BLANK4] of the evaluation may differ from clinical settings. Psychologists conducting research must inform participants about the [BLANK5] of their data as part of informed consent.
questions.explanation: Confidentiality operates differently across settings. In group therapy, psychologists cannot guarantee other members' confidentiality behavior. Telepsychology requires secure, encrypted platforms compliant with HIPAA. Standard 4.07 governs didactic use of confidential material (teaching, writing, presentations). Forensic settings have different confidentiality parameters because the evaluee may not be the client, and findings may be disclosed to courts or attorneys. Research participants must understand how their data will be protected, stored, and potentially shared.

questions.stem: A psychologist receives a subpoena from an attorney requesting complete therapy records for a client involved in a custody dispute. The client has not signed a release of information. The psychologist is unsure how to respond.
questions.centerQuestion: What is the primary ethical consideration in this situation?

options.text: A subpoena alone does not require release of records; a court order does
Client's right to confidentiality must be balanced against legal process
Complete records may contain information beyond what is legally relevant
The attorney is the psychologist's client and deserves full cooperation
Contact the client to inform them of the subpoena and discuss options
Consult with an attorney about the legal requirements in the jurisdiction
Send complete records immediately to comply with the subpoena
Consider filing a motion to quash or limit the scope of disclosure

questions.explanation: The primary ethical consideration is Standard 4.01 (Maintaining Confidentiality). A subpoena is NOT the same as a court order; psychologists have an obligation to protect client confidentiality and should not automatically comply with a subpoena without client consent or a court order. The psychologist should notify the client, consult with an attorney, and may seek to quash or narrow the subpoena. Simply sending complete records would be a potential confidentiality violation.

questions.stem: A psychologist working in a hospital is treating an inpatient for severe depression. The patient's family members arrive and demand to know the patient's diagnosis, medication regimen, and what was said during therapy sessions. The family members state they are paying for the treatment and have a right to know.
questions.centerQuestion: What is the primary ethical standard that governs the psychologist's response?

options.text: Payment for services does not automatically grant access to confidential treatment information
The patient is an adult with the right to control disclosure of their own information
Family involvement may be therapeutically beneficial but must be balanced with confidentiality
The family has an absolute legal right to all treatment information because they are paying
Explain that the patient's confidentiality must be respected and that information can only be shared with the patient's consent
Offer to facilitate a conversation between the patient and family about what the patient is comfortable sharing
Provide complete treatment details to satisfy the family and maintain the therapeutic alliance with them
Discuss with the patient the potential benefits of involving family in treatment while respecting the patient's autonomy

centerOptions.text: Standard 4.02: Discussing the Limits of Confidentiality

questions.explanation: Standard 4.01 (Maintaining Confidentiality) is the primary standard. An adult patient's confidentiality rights are not waived because a family member pays for treatment. The psychologist must protect the patient's information and can only share with the patient's explicit consent. However, the psychologist can therapeutically encourage the patient to consider involving family and can facilitate that conversation if the patient agrees. Providing information simply because family members demand it would violate confidentiality regardless of who pays.

questions.stem: A clinical psychologist is preparing a continuing education presentation on confidentiality. Highlight the THREE accurate statements about Standard 4 provisions:
questions.passage: (A) Confidentiality protections end completely when a client terminates therapy. (B) Psychologists must discuss the relevant limits of confidentiality at the outset of the professional relationship and as new circumstances warrant. (C) Psychologists may disclose confidential information only with written consent; verbal consent is never sufficient. (D) When consulting with colleagues, psychologists should avoid disclosing information that could identify the client unless consent has been obtained. (E) Psychologists must include in their records only information necessary for the provision and continuity of services. (F) A psychologist has no obligation to protect confidentiality when working with minors since parents have full access rights. (G) Standard 4.07 addresses the use of confidential information for teaching, writing, or other public purposes, requiring disguise of identifying details or consent.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (B) Standard 4.02 requires discussing limits at outset and as warranted; (D) Standard 4.06 addresses consultation confidentiality; (G) Standard 4.07 addresses use of confidential information publicly. Incorrect: (A) Confidentiality extends beyond termination; (C) The standard does not require written consent exclusively; (E) While minimizing intrusions, the standard doesn't limit records to only treatment-necessary information; (F) Minors have some confidentiality protections even from parents, varying by jurisdiction.

questions.stem: A psychologist is training new staff on HIPAA and APA Ethics Code confidentiality requirements. Highlight the FOUR statements that accurately describe obligations under Standard 4:
questions.passage: (A) Standard 4.01 requires reasonable precautions to protect confidential information in all media, including electronic records, paper files, and verbal communications. (B) Once a client gives verbal permission to share information, the psychologist has no further obligation to limit what is disclosed. (C) Standard 4.02 requires that the limits of confidentiality be discussed at the outset and whenever new circumstances arise that may affect confidentiality. (D) Psychologists have a duty to disclose all information to any law enforcement officer who requests it, even without a warrant or court order. (E) Standard 4.05 recognizes that psychologists may disclose without consent to protect the client or identifiable others from serious harm. (F) Standard 4.06 requires that consultations be conducted with appropriate care to avoid unnecessary disclosure of identifying information. (G) Confidentiality obligations do not apply to information obtained during psychological assessments, only during therapy. (H) A psychologist may share complete session transcripts with a client's new therapist without consent if the psychologist believes it would benefit the client.
questions.explanation: (A) Standard 4.01 covers all media including electronic and verbal. (C) Standard 4.02 requires ongoing discussion of limits, not just at intake. (E) Standard 4.05 permits disclosure to protect from serious harm. (F) Standard 4.06 requires care during consultations. Incorrect: (B) Even with consent, the psychologist should share only what is germane. (D) Law enforcement requests do not automatically override confidentiality without legal authority. (G) Confidentiality applies across all professional activities. (H) Consent is required before sharing records with a new therapist.

questions.stem: Arrange the steps a psychologist should take when receiving a subpoena for client records, in the correct order:

options.text: Consult with an attorney about legal obligations and options
Review the subpoena to determine its scope and requirements
If required to disclose, release only the minimum necessary information
Contact the client to inform them and discuss options, including potential waiver or motion to quash
Document all steps taken and the rationale for the final decision

questions.explanation: The proper sequence: First, review the subpoena to understand what is being requested (scope, timeline, issuing authority). Then, contact the client because they have the right to know and to decide whether to waive confidentiality or challenge the subpoena. Consult with an attorney about legal obligations. If disclosure is ultimately required (by court order or client waiver), release only the minimum necessary information. Document all steps and rationale throughout the process.

questions.stem: Arrange the steps a psychologist should take when a client reveals intent to harm an identifiable third party, from first to last:

options.text: Document the threat assessment, clinical decision-making process, and all actions taken
Assess the credibility, specificity, and imminence of the threat through clinical interview
If the threat is deemed credible, take steps to protect the identifiable potential victim (e.g., warn victim, notify law enforcement)
Attempt to address the threat therapeutically if clinically appropriate and safe (e.g., voluntary hospitalization, safety planning)
Inform the client about the limits of confidentiality regarding duty to protect, if not already discussed

questions.explanation: The correct sequence for managing a threat to a third party: First, assess the threat's credibility, specificity, and imminence through careful clinical evaluation. Then inform (or remind) the client about the limits of confidentiality regarding threats to others. Attempt therapeutic interventions if safe and appropriate (voluntary hospitalization, crisis intervention, safety planning). If the threat remains credible and imminent, take protective action (warning the victim, contacting law enforcement, or both, depending on jurisdiction). Finally, document the entire process including the threat assessment, clinical reasoning, and all actions taken. Documentation should be completed throughout but the summary should follow the resolution.

questions.stem: An ethics consultation service tracks the types of confidentiality questions received over 5 years:

questions.question: What event most likely caused the sharp increase in telepsychology security questions in 2020?

options.text: New APA Ethics Code revision
COVID-19 pandemic driving rapid adoption of telepsychology
State laws banning in-person therapy
Reduction in insurance reimbursement for in-person services

questions.question: What does the persistent elevation of telepsychology questions after 2020 suggest?

options.text: Telepsychology will completely replace in-person therapy
Telepsychology became a permanent part of practice, creating ongoing confidentiality challenges
Electronic confidentiality concerns have been fully resolved
Psychologists are no longer concerned about duty to warn/protect

questions.explanation: The COVID-19 pandemic (2020) drove a massive, rapid shift to telepsychology, creating a surge in electronic confidentiality questions. The sustained elevation after 2020 indicates telepsychology became a permanent practice modality with ongoing confidentiality challenges (encryption, platform security, interstate practice, client privacy in home settings). Duty to warn and subpoena questions remained relevant but decreased proportionally as electronic security concerns dominated.

questions.stem: A state psychology board reviews data on the types of confidentiality complaints filed against licensed psychologists over a 10-year period. The data shows the percentage of Standard 4 complaints by subcategory:

datasets.name: Failure to discuss limits at outset complaints (%)

questions.question: What does the dramatic spike in electronic/digital confidentiality complaints in 2020 reflect?

options.text: Psychologists deliberately chose insecure platforms to save money
The rapid, often unprepared transition to telepsychology during COVID-19 exposed gaps in digital confidentiality practices
Clients became less concerned about privacy during the pandemic
Insurance companies required less secure documentation practices

questions.question: What does the gradual decline in electronic/digital complaints after 2021 suggest?

options.text: Psychologists stopped providing telepsychology services
The profession adapted by implementing HIPAA-compliant platforms and developing telehealth-specific informed consent procedures
Clients stopped filing complaints about digital breaches
The APA removed electronic confidentiality requirements

questions.explanation: The spike in electronic/digital confidentiality complaints in 2020-2021 reflects the rapid, often unprepared shift to telepsychology during COVID-19. Many psychologists initially used non-HIPAA-compliant platforms, lacked telehealth-specific informed consent procedures, and were unfamiliar with digital security practices. The subsequent decline suggests the profession successfully adapted through adoption of secure platforms, development of telehealth-specific consent forms, and increased training in digital confidentiality. The steady decline in unauthorized disclosure complaints may reflect improved general confidentiality training over time.

questions.stem: Categorize each situation according to the appropriate confidentiality action under Standard 4:

items.text: Suspected child abuse reported by a client
Client expresses general frustration about their marriage
Client makes a credible threat to kill a specific identifiable person
Client's employer calls requesting session details without client consent
Suspected elder abuse disclosed in session
Colleague asks about a client's diagnosis out of curiosity

questions.explanation: Legally mandated disclosures: Child abuse (item1) and elder abuse (item5) are mandatory reporting situations in all states. Permitted disclosures: A credible threat to an identifiable person (item3) may trigger duty to warn/protect depending on jurisdiction. Prohibited disclosures: General marital frustration (item2) is routine therapy content; employer requests without consent (item4) and curious colleague inquiries (item6) are not exceptions to confidentiality.

questions.stem: Categorize each action according to the Standard 4 provision it most directly relates to:

categories.label: Standard 4.04/4.07: Minimizing Intrusions and Didactic Use

items.text: Explaining to a new client that the psychologist is a mandated reporter for child and elder abuse
Using encrypted email for all electronic communication with clients
Disguising a client's identity when presenting a case at a professional conference
Informing a group therapy client that the psychologist cannot guarantee other members will keep information confidential
Obtaining written consent before video recording a therapy session
Redacting irrelevant personal information from records before complying with a court order for limited records

questions.explanation: Standard 4.01/4.03: Using encryption (item2) is a reasonable precaution for maintaining confidentiality; obtaining consent for recording (item5) is required by Standard 4.03. Standard 4.02: Explaining mandated reporting (item1) and informing about group members' potential breaches (item4) are discussions of confidentiality limits at the outset. Standard 4.04/4.07: Disguising identity for a conference presentation (item3) falls under Standard 4.07 (didactic use); redacting irrelevant information from court-ordered records (item6) falls under Standard 4.04 (minimizing intrusions on privacy).
